results.title: Game plan for survival (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Dr. George Sheehan, Dr. Kenneth Cooper and other health professionals encourage viewers to select their own regular exercise program to avoid the maladies associated with sedentary and stressful lifestyles.

results.title: Game of Thrones
results.brief_description: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Friction between the houses leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night’s Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.

constellations_other.name: The Hatfield House rules
constellations_other.description: The shooting location of The Favourite, Hatfield House, has appeared in a number of other iconic works.

constellations_other.name: Significant sounds
constellations_other.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title: Game Masters: Yuji Naka interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yuji Naka is a videogame designer and programmer, best known as the former head of Sonic Team, where he was the lead programmer of the original ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’. Naka reveals his initial desire to make arcade games and the influence that Yu Suzuki has had on his career as a programmer. Since 2006 he has been the head of Prope, an independent game company he founded after leaving SEGA.
Yuji gives great insights into the development and creation of ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 1 and 2’, ‘Nights into Dreams’ and ‘Chu Chu Rocket’.
NB: This interview was conducted in Yuji Naka’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Yu Suzuki interview
results.brief_description:
Yu Suzuki talks about his body of work which is one of the most diverse in the industry, ranging from the adrenalin rushes of his early arcade hits ‘Space Harrier’ (1985) and ‘Hang-On’ (1985) to the console adventure epic ‘Shenmue’ (1999).

As the pioneer of immersive, full-body arcade games, Suzuki has never been afraid to explore fantasy, reality and every shade of virtual experience in between.

In 1999, Suzuki moved away from arcades to create ‘Shenmue’ (1999), an open-world adventure for the Dreamcast. ‘Shenmue’ was recognised at the time as one of the most expansive and detailed videogames ever made; it pioneered the ‘open city’ subgenre of open-world games.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Warren Spector interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Warren Spector speaks about his career as a videogame designer. Warren refers to his days of playing ‘Dungeons and Dragons’ and the influence this has had on him as a vidoegames designer. A great collector of board games and Disney memorabilia, Warren talks with great passion about the importance of archiving and making games a medium worth recognising.

Warren Spector is a master of role playing game design and has been influenced and inspired by films and literature, such as ‘Blade Runner’ and cyberpunk science fiction, he is best known for creating influential titles such as ‘Deus Ex’ and his most recent release, ‘Disney Epic Mickey’.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Tim Schafer interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Content Development, ACMI Media Studio and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the Game Masters exhibition, Tim Schafer speaks about his career as a game designer, starting at LucasArts and then founding his own production company Double Fine Productions. Tim discusses his influences, drawn heavily from the cultural folk law of Mexico, the psychological study of dreams, his love of heavy metal music and the writing of Raymond Chandler and Kurt Vonnegut Jr. With the progression of emerging technology his game aesthetics and character development have evolved, cementing Tim Schafer and Double Fine Productions’ place in games history.

Tim talks about his inspirations and work practices in developing the following games: ‘Full Throttle’, ‘Grim Fandango’, ‘Psychonauts’ and ‘Brutal Legend’. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Tetsuya Mizuguchi interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Tetsuya Mizuguchi started in the industry working for SEGA developing arcade games such as ‘Sega Rally’. In 1994 he was inspired by the street parades in Zurich and soon turned his love of synaesthesia, combining sound and vision, to produce the games ‘Rez’ and ‘Space Channel 5’. Mizuguchi continues to incorporate a notable emphasis on interactive sound design, with his latest game ‘Child of Eden’.

Currently he is co-founder of the videogame development firm Q Entertainment. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Rob Murray interview
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Rob Murray speaks about his career as a game designer. Starting out as a solo developer for hire to becoming CEO of Firemint, Murray is one of the most successful indie game developers in existence.

Firemint’s success is due to Murray’s vision to create games such as ‘Flight Control’(2009) and’ Real Racing’ (2009), which are both easy to play and elegant and addictive in equal measure. In addition, his prescient reading of the drive towards personalised gaming, led by the ubiquity of social networking on mobile platforms, has kept his games on trend – ‘Flight Control’, for example, allows players to choose music from their personal libraries to accompany the game.

Rob talks about the rise of mobile based gaming and the development of ‘Flight Control’ and ‘Real Racing’ .
